reviewText:
Kinetic Void started off as a really good idea for a game. 100% open world, pure 'do-as-you-wish' ship construction and exploration.

That's about all the good I can say about it.

The dev team was really small, inexperienced, and although they were pretty active in the community and media, the game itself fell short by many expectations. There are still a lot of bugs, no actual tutorial, ship building in itself is pretty complicated, and the game overall is not really well optimized.

When it boiled down to release I started to regret my purchase as despite the fact it's no longer Early Access, the game itself still feels largely incomplete. Buggy, no tutorial whatsoever, still not well optimized to run, and the ship building, although the interface is better, it still is really complicated a workflow overall. Not even the missions would work correctly. Which was a pain.

Of course, having already purchased this game I decided to cling on and hope for the best, but then suddenly, the game went quiet on all mediums: forum, update schedule, and youtube.

The entire dev team dropped out of the KV project, pretty much leaving only 2 behind. While it's more of a lack of interest than a 'take money and run' scheme (funds went to dev salaries), the 2 developers that DID stay behind, as much as I'd like to applaud them, can't do much either, not when they are also trying to work on a side project to make ends meet.

I bought the game with high hopes that were never repaid. If you're here looking for a space sandbox, there are other, much better games that haven't been abandoned and left to rot in the pits of Steam. Don't buy this. It was never worth the $20, and never will be.

reviewText:
Here's a really good example of why Steam GreenLight usually doesn't work as planned.

Originally I invested in this game for the idea, knowing full well it would be a while before development finished. However, the stunning slowness and absolute lack of proper patching didn't even remotely keep me interested to boot up the game. The few hours I messed around with it showed promise, especially in the ship building aspect. Unfortunately, this is real life -- developers get lazy, lose motivation, perhaps funding gets cut.

This is exactly why Steam GreenLight was a failure. In retrospect, it's a good idea -- sometimes developers need help or the extra customer funding to push their game to the max. Keen Software is a good example of how to do it; they engage in their community very often, an update is out once every 1-2 weeks reflecting some sort of desire or functionality customers wanted, and it is well-recieved and fleshed out to be a game of its own. Badland Studio had promises, but fell short; a disappointment of a company at best.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's a shame because this game has so much potential. The only thing good I have to say about this is that the ship creator is bloody brilliant. Real customisation to exactly where you want your weapons, cockpit, engines etc. If it's going cheap it's worth a go just to build a few ships and get really creative.
Outside the space station though. MEH. There isn't really anything to do. If you're lucky a mission might pop up, and you're even luckier if you're properly equipped to do it. Icons of asteroids litter the screen with no real method of filtering other than 'HUD off'. and the game lacks any real.. anything. So.. Mining the identical poo drop shaped asteroids over and over again for money gets boring very quickly, and for some reason they just explode when you've mined them. This tiny ship can blow up an item that is probably kilometers wide.. with.. mining lasers. NOPE.
Planets are empty and don't even have names.. There's no one really to talk to, at all. Would have been nice to hail other ships even if it was just for trading. The little cockpit man that pops up every time you fart or blink gets irritating, just text would have sufficed for the 60th Silicates you mined.
After nearly 3 years of development I'm severely disappointed. Yeah some aspects are good. But it's not playable and it's not a game. What a joke.

reviewText:
Despite the negative reviews I decided it looked like the kind of game I would really enjoy... To be honest, I can't tell you if I enjoy the game or not, since I can't get past just how counter intuitive the ship building interface is. All I want to do is mirror a damn part. You have the tool, you click it, and as for mirroring? lets see, if by some miracle you do manage to get them to mirror.... they will be offset on the z axis, so they just wont align, and can you switch between the parts to do fine adjustment, nope, that button doesn't seem to do a damn thing. Either it's just not meant to do that, or whatever, but that's what I would think it would do... Dear devolopers, have you ever used any 3d modeling software? do you have any idea what 'mirror' means? I have spent the last hour since downloading it, trying to make a mirror image of a hull part. that's all I want to do. As it is, I'm going to just slap a bunch of parts together, throw some engines on it and call it good. I really hope that the actual game play isn't as counter intuitive as the ship building interface. Save your money folks, even on sale it isn't worth what I paid for it. Games are supposed to be fun, relaxing, enjoyable. Not vexing to the point of making any possible enjoyment moot.

Update: After another 3 hours of messing with the ship designer, I figured out a few tricks to actually make the parts line up as a mirror image of eachother, but naturally, it is not how you'd think you'd be able to pull it off. Anyways made the ship, launched, got a mission message, and it was very vague.

Managed to mine the required materials, and now I have no idea where to take them...

Suggestion for the developer, go play Freelancer. Compare what you attempted to do with the 'freelance' mode of the game. get a mission, it tells you where to go, add a module, it shows what it does, how it affects everything.

The KV interface is crap. It's a nice idea, but there's too much of the wrong information, and not enough of the right information. Buttons get hidden, the touch location changes, little bugs, that are obnoxious.

It's nice that it's an open sandbox, and you get to choose where you get to go and when you go there, but what's the point if the game expects you to guess where you're suppoed to go to?

Save your money, and your frustration.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs most reviews have said up to now, KV is in Early Access, and thus has a long way to go. That being said, the fact that it does have a ways to go is less of a reminder than something to look forward to(as is often the case in Early Access games) as this game is remarkably whole. You generate a universe, build a ship(or if that's not your thing there are plenty of perfectly fine pre-built ships), and launch it into space. You fly around vaporizing enemies(or getting vaporized...you'll learn your limitations very quickly) and completing missions, and, if your hull is about to crumble or you decide you can do better with the design, you return to the ship yard and make adjustments. As it stands, the missions do need work, as they are random and can become repetitive, and the help center and be opaque to people starting out, but for those looking for a space sim because of exactly what it is: a sim, this game is excellent.

reviewText:
I bought this game in early access.  Suffice to say that steam did not allow refunds at the time.

I found it hard to ever play this game, and now, seeing it in my library, I read the reviews to find that it might have gotten worse.

If history is to look back at why steam's greenlighting system is broken, it must include this game/developer as an example.

That said, kudos to the game developer, because it is not easy to make games - certainly even this one.  However, this game is a perfect example of how an indie game can be overhyped (and overpriced), thus racheting up people's expectations.

On the back-drop of so many other space games (and even the re-release of some classics) I see no reason to recommend this game.  If anyone does like this game they owe it to the developer and all of steam to explain themselves.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of now, I cannot personally RECOMMEND that any consumer should buy this game for entertainment. Not in its current early access state. However! I can say that this game is currently moving on rails to success. After you read this review, please buy the game to show the developers some financial and informational support. Now to the actual game itself!

Graphical aesthetics are great and match with the atmosphere. The soundtracks are perfect for inducing that soothing yet unsettling feel of colossal space. planets, and that vibrant, atmosphereic scifi feel.  Listen to it here. That is a reason that I was seduced into buying the game. As always, its the screenshots or cover of that book that you should not judge yet. As I segwayed further into the game, I was brought along a smooth road to introduction. The tutorial is a large ingame wiki, however I hope remake it into a more clever tutorial system. Well all hate tutorials that makes us feel like we are accomplishing nothing; I think virtually all of them are like that. It is hard not to do so. Skyrim did a good job with their tutorial. It was taught well as you were contributing to the story and felt a sense of accomplishment through it as you gt your first weapons, and always wanted to know who would live or die and what would happen next. I am getting off topic, perhaps I should give my adhd brain a break and finish the review later. . .

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent custom ship builder. Though the sub-systems are a bit tricky to locate. Space is big, open, and empty. Ship to ship combat seems ok, though the trading aspect is a bit confusing. Controls and UI not too terrible, though some further explanation or a tutorial would greatly improve things.

Could use a better mission system. Repeatedly saw messages pop up without any way to know where the mission was, or who the target was. Only missions seem to be combat based. Planet based stations would be a nice addition, though maybe I just didn't find any.

Overall, this is a fun game, but I don't see myself spending a great deal of time on it as it is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent custom ship builder. Though the sub-systems are a bit tricky to locate. Space is big, open, and empty. Ship to ship combat seems ok, though the trading aspect is a bit confusing. Controls and UI not too terrible, though some further explanation or a tutorial would greatly improve things.

Could use a better mission system. Repeatedly saw messages pop up without any way to know where the mission was, or who the target was. Only missions seem to be combat based. Planet based stations would be a nice addition, though maybe I just didn't find any.

Overall, this is a fun game, but I don't see myself spending a great deal of time on it as it is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to like this game, but I'm still trying to figure out how to play it.  Ship design is neato.  There's subsystems that you assign to various parts, big ol' cannons, etc.  I just figured out how to get the shields into a design.  Finally having created a ship that would launch, I then popped into a very large area where some AI ship called me 'fresh meat.'

I blasted away at what I thought was an enemy (after reading the help on the controls) .. brought his shields all the way down, and he didn't even return fire.  I wonder if he was an enemy?  Who knows!

Looking forward to more updates, but I shouldn't have bought it yet.

Update -- The forums do have a ton of information.  Watching the tutorial videos helped a lot.  There's still a lot of work to do, but I'm changing my vote to a Thumbs up if you don't mind betas""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well you can't get any more sandbox than generated galaxies, ships built module-by-module and a variety of factions that differ from galaxy to galaxy. Kinetic Void has the potential to be a great game.

It is still in development, however, and is lacking some important features. Right now, I'd still rather play X3... or even X Rebirth. But that is not to say that game has no future. How will it compare with Star Citizen? Well I think it might be able to top the single-player sandbox experience (given Star Citizen will be an instanced MMO), but the game feels a little arcady at present, and don't get me started on joystick support.

I'd recomment this game merely for trying out the ship building and galaxy generation features, but I wouldn't call its gameplay enticing just yet. Give it a few.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I came into the store one day, and while I was looking through the gaming archives for a new passtime, this popped up. I looked at the reviews, they didn't turn out too bad, so I took an immediate interest due to the pictures and effective wording done by the game developers of how it works, and also because of its' high praise by other players. So I bought, and downloaded it.

After starting the game, a series of menus (the game played without much lag at all, it seems to be very effectively coded) that brought me to the ship creation menu. The whole thing was obviously still in development, as is the whole game, so I wasn't fazed. So far, it seems to have a solid menu system, and I love and hope that they try to make a little more sense of the icons, numbers, subsystems and such, because it wasn't all clear as to what they did, or meant, or how they affected the ship.

So, after a few minutes of confused silence, I decided to choose one of the pre-made ships, and set off on my journey through space.

I had fun. The distances were ridiculous, and the slip-space mechanic was a bit underdeveloped, but hey, it's a still-in-progress. What do you expect?

Then I went into the fighting mode, in which I was destroyed in seconds, and had a good laugh at how horrible I was at simulators, and confused as to how exactly the weapons functioned. Once they did fire at the enemies, however, their power was surprisingly underwhelming.

I see a lot of promise in this recently-aquired game, though I've barely tapped into its' evidently deep wells of entertainment. I do reccomend this game as it will continue to develop, and the onward march of progress is a brilliant thing to behold.

Early Access Review

The ship customization is certainly promising but at the stage of development I played it, I couldn't even figure out how to start a ship's engines without rifling through several videos on YouTube.

Of course I own a copy of the game now, so whenever it is released I'll muck about with the game at that time and change this review accordingly. But for now, I'd advise you to just go toss your money at Chris Roberts' face because he's awesome and stuff.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATE /// 8-22-14
Game as far as construction of ships is far more functional than when I first got the game if not buggy and great strides have been made in this area to make it approachable. However once you get into the game itself the fundimental problems with the game shine through again.

Kinetic Void tries to reinvent the space sim wheel by making it square.  Controls are overly complicated for flight and space feels empty. Both of these problems have been solved by games made over a decade ago like Freelancer. Mouse flight needs to be implemented better. Warp gates need to be added to define sections of space. Weapons need to feel more powerful and stand out more. Procedural galaxies need to be dropped and replaced with a designed galaxy unless they can make them interesting which they currently are not. I could go on and on about how this game ignores problems that have been solved by older, better games.

My suggestion... save your money. Early Access games either have good bones that need to be fleshed out or they're like Kinetic Void where all they have is a good idea but no idea how to impliment it into a good game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kinetic Void - Great ideas and concept, yet extremely unfinished and Work in Progress.

At this point in time KV is very much an early alpha - if it is even that. Consider waiting on a more finished version, unless you are a big fan of custom ship building and have little interest in actually using the ship in question.

Even the ship building itself is at this time incomplete. There is only one type of weaponry and many other critical features are still missing. The rate of update/patch progress is extremely slow.

From my point of view as a gamer, avoid KV for now, but keep an eye on it. IF, and I stress the word IF, all of the promised features are actually going to get implemented some time in the future, this could turn out to be a very cool space sim. However given the current rate of updates and the state of the game, I expect KV to be a project that will never end with a high likelihood of never getting to the finish line at all.

reviewText:
Building my first ship was fun. It had a couple issues, namely that they gave you too many free parts instead of, say, a budget and a store, but it was fun to put a ship together from scratch(ish, it is modular after-all).

But you hit launch with every anticipation and you get. . . ugh.

X3 and Eve Online, pick solo or MMO and go play, because this? Not worth the time. To be perfectly honest, I warped to an asteroid, started mining, looked around empty space for a few minutes, realized how long mining was going to take, adn then? Then I realized the 'world' was far too empty to have anything to do with, to spend that kind of time waiting, especially without at least a chat-box to pass the time! Seriously, I cannot understand why games that cannot compete with such old predecessors keep getting released. The best game to come out since either of those was S.P.A.Z. . . which isn't exactly the same kind of game really, but it does the job. So, you could buy that instead as well. It isn't so much with the full-immersion 'you are your ship' exploration thing, but it is a solid game.

reviewText: Anyone who's ever played early access games knows (or should) that this sort of thing is a possibility. Funding is a major problem with small developers, and many either don't plan well the proccess from start to finish ahead of time, things just don't go as expected, or they lose their minds and fall to stressors. Whatever the reason, we'll always end up with abandoned, or so called abandoned games. I've had it happen multiple times. I don't feel angry or regret it in the least. Because without the faith and support, we'd be missing some very nice games. You should wholly expect this when you see 'Early Access' and press that buy button.\n\nThis particular game? If you're nosy about the awesome ship builder, and it goes on sale, sure, might be worth poking. Just don't expect a game. Else don't waste the money on what's essentially a set of legos that you can only share with screenshots. We can hope that the developers return to this game later with proper funding, but I wouldn't get my hopes up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kinetic Void is a stellar example of what many space related games should be.  Mind you while in early access many things are bound to change.  This game has a ship design system very akin to that used in Galactic Civilizations 2 which should be counted as a good thing.  The amount of customization that is offered to players in the design of their ships is a welcome sight as it’s something I have seen lacking in several games with the same feature.  From building the fastest fighter to the most looming dreadnought the experience of testing out different parts and experimenting with style is a great joy.

Players are allowed to name their galaxy and select how many sectors and factions exist within, giving them some level of control of the environment that they start off with.  There is plenty of room for expansion in this area of the game’s development as further options in creating the play environment would add to the overall experience.

The combat system is decent but could use some work.  While offering a manual mode of firing your ships weapons, there is a means of auto fire via the lock on, and pressing the assigned weapons group number.  In this early build I recommend avoiding the use of the auto fire as my weapons seemed resistant to firing let alone hitting.  However due warning, there does not appear to be any form of aim assist for now, and larger ships will have issues contending with smaller vessels you just cannot seem to hit.  (I am sure that these features will be ironed out in the future)

Other than that there really isn’t that much left to do within the game, yet currently you can see the foundations for what have the potential to be engaging and immersive systems.

I full heartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys building ships from the ground up and actually being able to use them, as well as to anyone who enjoys space simulation games.  For what this game could be twenty dollars is a fair investment into seeing the developers get the chance to finish this game.  Yet to be fair it should be mentioned that in its current state Kinetic Void is arguably worth its asking price, while I love building ships and taking them for a spin there is just not enough to do currently.  With the occasional frame rate issue and bugs, for those on a budget or those who are not willing to drop twenty dollars on an incomplete game I would still recommend getting this game but when it is on sale.  This way you can still support the game, get a great ship builder, and access to what has the potential to be a great game.

reviewText:
Picked up this game for full price during Early Access. Had a fair amount of fun building some cool-looking ships. An update made all previous work in te game incompatible with the latest version, so I left for a while, unwilling to repeat the entire building process again. It was barely, barely playable at this stage. I could make a ship, warp in, fly around, and that was it.

I cam back after a long absence, and the game has gotten much, much worse. The UI now looks and acts even clunkier than ever, the ship builder has become a visual nightmare of complexity for no resaon, the game itself still has practically nothing to do (if you're lucky, you might pick up a distress call - but good luck trying to do anything about it) ; essentially, it feels and looks totally unfinished in every regard. It's like the Marie Celeste of space sims.

So I started looking at the Behind The Scenes posts to see what was going on. Woeful mismanagement by the dev, bad use of funding and coding time, and staff departures have led to this game being, essentially, abandoned. this didnt come as a shock, but it was a severe disappointment - I'd been lauding this game previously, leading some freinds to buy it, and had been excited to see new features myself - only to recieve nothing in return.

TL:DR - do not buy this game. Do not support the developer until they can redeem themselves in some way (just being honest doesnt count). Check reviews and forums before buying a game, and for now, don't trust early access titles.

reviewText:
I bought this game quite early in its release, and have checked in on it about once a month or so. I have to say that the games progress has been extremely dissapointing. It really feels like a mix of the devs losing inspiration and focus on little here and there items on their fix-it lists and no longer try to focus on the big picture or the concepts that made this game sound so appealing in the first place. This game really has the feel of a team that had a very ambitious concept but as many other teams, just could not bring that ambitious concept to life as intended.

From the time I have started with this game, all the way to this day here are the following things I have noticed about the game itself... It lacks the feel of a true game with little to no real direction or incentive. Of course in some sandbox style games this can be acceptable, but this game is so devoid of anything of worth that the game world isn't worth being in with your created ship. This is a MAJOR downside and this game is in severe need of more variety and direction. The ship creator however complex, has little to guide you, and even less to really inspire you unless you are good at looking at a blank screen and scrolling through menu's to put your great works of art together. That is basically the ONLY point of this game at this moment.

They have added random somewhat or completely nonsensical features that just don't fit the game at its current build, such as other ships roaming around, or 'factions', but none of it matters at this time. At this rate this game will most likely remain incomplete unless they find a new ambition or give the game to another team to breathe new life into it. Unless this happens, I do not reccomend you buy this game, even if it is on sale its not worth the money currently.

I will update this review monthly to bi-monthly to let you all know if anything has changed, or things have been added that increases this games worth/value. As always I hope for the best with this and any game. They had great ideas and concepts to work with, but the execution has been extremely poor and uninspired.

Final Verdict: DO NOT BUY AT FULL PRICE OR ON SALE. Overall: 1/10 Sound: 0/10 Gameplay: 0/10 Concept: 6/10 Ability to create/customize: 5/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in Early Alpha stage. So I took that in consideration and looked in the long run. Not just as to what it offers at the moment.


Kinetic Void is a new genre of Spaceship Simulator. Having it's roots from the old freelancer and other games from the genre, it bring us new aspects of the game. Creating your own ship.

Kinetic void let the players create their own ships, the way they want. You are able to design and create the ships you want for any purpose that may suite you. Want a nice looking sleek ship? Go ahead and make one. Want a big though ship like the Galactica? Go Ahead. And when we talk about creating ship, the Devs have gone further then just looks. All of the ship needs, from the power to radars, to crew quarters are your to choice to decide where they go. And to protect these important systems is one of your goal. Having, technically, no limits, you can build any ship you would have though about.

But creating ships is not the only aspect. If this is something that is not your taste, you can simply take some of the default ship, or why not download some designs from the community workshop? Having over  thousands of community created ships, there is a ship for everyone out there... If designing is not your taste.

Kinetic void launches you in a Procedural Generation world where Factions of NPCs each struggling to survive and conquer the galaxy in their own own. You are sent in this sandbox word with one goal: Living your life how  you want it. You want to be a merchant, selling Goods around the universe? Go ahead. Want to be a smuggler and go past blockades? Want to just shoot at things and be a pirate? Or defend the innocent? All is yours to decide.


Kinetic Void aims to  be one of the, if not the space sim with the most opened up world, with the most customized game possible and it does it in a way that makes  you wonder: Why no one though of this before?


If you are a fan of any space ship simulator, Kinetic Void is a must. From it's amazing artwork, to the infinity of customization, to the hard work of the Team, there's absolutely no reason not to have this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYou can't save your progress yourself. The game does it for you sometimes. Then when you try to load your previous game it won't let you. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is lightyears from finished. And they make it somewhat unclear what exactly you can do in game right now. date: it should not be for the sake of the game))
recommended: and complete glitchy and random quests (or at least try to).\n\nShip building is certainly the phase where people spend the most time on (at least for now). The ship building is like a gimpy artistic outlet where you can create almost anything as you imagine it. It's almost like legos... but not quite. It's actually more like the generic brand of slightly out of shape bootleg lego pieces. You really couldn't build to your heart's content with them because they looked weird compared to the legit lego pieces. That's how I feel about this game right now... Building your own ship is nice
hoursPlayed: but the problem lies with what you can build with. The parts you can build with are currently preset and are very limited in variety (also I'm pretty sure a few of the pieces showcased in screenshots and trailers are missing in game). Along with that

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n(The rating is only for the current version its at itself) 8/10, This game is absolutely fantastic in my eyes, its got alot of bugs and parts wrong with it which is VERY understandable as its in Early Development, a few problems i ran into so far, some Game related the other ME related, firstly the mirroring system still needs abit of work, if you click and object to place and have not placed it just yet, you can turn the mirroring tool on and it works perfectly, but if you place (at the part where you can use the Arrows or loops to move/rotate) If you were to mirror once you've placed, it would go really weird, it wouldnt be mirrored at all, a problem that is most likely me related is, Every time i get in to this one galaxy that i've had created, I'm only in a corvette because after finishing up on that ship i came to realise you can make a BIGGER ship by clicking the number box above the construction menu *Derp* I keep getting swarmed upon spawn and as a noobie, even after figuring out the controls it gets abit hard to fight back which means i obviously either need a BIGGER ship, BETTER ship or just get better at the game haha xD but Oh my god, the Construction mechanics on this game, by far some of the best i've ever seen, i've been looking around for a damn long time for a game where you can have a HUGE Wide Free range of customization to your very own ship and the fact that I heard that hopefully this game would be getting multiplayer somewhile after the base game is complete, I was swooning, showing off your amazingly or Crazily made ships to your friends and facing off in battle just makes me drool! I have so much high hopes for this game and i've only managed to find out when it was on sale, i would of gladly payed the full price! (If and when i had the money xD) but this is a game for all Space Adventurers with a craving of customizing your very own ship to as much detail as the game can generate just for you, a Game i very much look forward to being completed by the development team! (as a wannabe Developer myself) I look up to you people, and i know almost everyone else does, so keep up the good work and to you people reading this, Take a chance, Buy this game and Hopefully you wont be disappointed!!!! Back up these Gorgeous Developers!!! <3

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is simply a Masterpiece. Truly giving the player the feeling that they're in a massive, open, and dangerous galaxy (which the player can make to an extent). Allowing players to make vesels of any shape and size; players can make speedy cargo ships to extremely large and powerful ships bent on destroying their enemies. reviewText: It is rare i write one of these, my time and words are not flung around lightly. This game is incredible fun even in its current state and i can only imagine what the future will hold. Currently it feels like a combination of Starmade and Eve. Starmade in how you build and manage your ships and Eve in how combat flows (But without insanely long buld times and skill trees ((yet???)) ). You can buid everything from tiny fighters to dreadnaughts the size of planets and beyond. Build you ship for looks or to focus your firepower tacticaly and as for guns....the new system gives you LOTS of options. The game has had it's bumps in the form of glitches but the creators actually listen to the community and talk with us to try to figure out whats going on so they can fix it. If i can hope for one thing to come it would be the ability to fly with friends.\n\nUpdate: The game now feels alive, so many ships flying about and reports coming in all the time keeping you up to date makes the game quite exciting now. All i can hope now flying about in space is that the developers really consider adding the ability of multiplayer. Flying about with friends or opening up a public server for massive clashes between player groups would be amazing. I can honestly see if this game gets multiplayer it becoming a cheaper and far easier alternative to EVE for people like me who refuse to pay monthly fees.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, so maybe it's just me being bad at games, but I can't seem to play this game still. I believe that you have to kill enemies to get more money so you can buy more ship parts to make you stronger or get supplies to mine. I'm stuck at the first step. I can't seem to come even close to defeating an enemy ship (usually they come in groups of two or three, so it's essentially impossible). I fire everything that I have, hit the ship so many times, but there health barely drops...and then regenerates. Mine, on the other hand get destroyed very easily.

So, I gave up on trying to fight for a while and decided to go exploring...that didn't work out either. I spent like five minutes using warp drive (or whatever the Kinetic Void version is), just to get out of that same starting area. I thought this was going to be easy, but apparently not. All that got me was five minutes away from everything. The only thing on my radar was that starting station. I also can't figure out the map.

Chances are, I'm missing something really obvious, but I watched their videos on combat and did everything that they did, but I still fail every fight with the enemy. An in-game tutorial is a must-have for games like this.

Once this game is complete, I would love to see it as a rival for the games in the X series, but it has a looooooooooooooong way to go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I bought this game, it seemed to potentially be a good game.  However after attempting to play it for 30 minutes, I've given up on it for the following reasons.

Default guidance of the ship seems to be the mouse, which when you have to use the mouse to utilize/close the windows that show up, can REALLY screw up where you're going.

It seems like that depending on your current situation, the default key for many different controls, USE THE SAME KEY BIND

zooming in/out.............why does it take several minutes of scrolling the mouse wheel to go from a close up of a single piece of your current ship to the point where you can now see.....*GASP* two pieces of the ship.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After shelving this game for sometime, I tried it again... aparently there has been massive amounts of work done on this game - just a shame I've not been able to see any of it...

After struggling through an overly complex ship design process, still no idea why I can only have 1 cargo module despite having plenty of room etc... you then get to launch your ship....

... to have it immediatly attacked outside the station - boom dead before even having a chance to manuver or even fire guns (or even work out how to target)

after this happened 4 times in a row - using different designs - I have to conclude this *might* be a game if only it were more understandable or at least had some kind of tutorial - other than an excuse of a tutorial which bassically looks like a VERY abridged manual....

One day after I've given the author further time to over complicate the game and I have about 60 hours free to read up on it and watch youtube I might even get some use out of this..... you never know....

I recommend it but watch the alpha state. Analyze whether it's worth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

you spend a loving 2 hours perfecting your ship, giving it a vibrant color scheme to suit the style and how you play
(will i be the red pirate with quad guns all down the sides? will i be the ho hum grey mining ship? oh, the choices i have) and set off into the vast abyss that is the last (dare i say, final) frontier. you will see stars and planets and be immersed in a galaxy that is teeming and alive. even at early access this game is fantastic and at the sale price of 12.99, you cannot go wrong.

don't get it twisted, this game is not finished. you will be running out of things to do at the current moment, but for me, im happy to just drift through space dictating my logs. that is until some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ side swipes my ship and flies off. then i gotta fill out a space hit and run, and talk to the space cops, and they are always unhappy cause they just came back from a triple space homicide, and they just wanna go drink....

to make a long ramble short, buy this game, and enjoy.

reviewText: This is a very complicated game that needs a softer introduction for inexperienced players.\n\nRight now the tutorial" presents a firehose of useful information without any experience using that information interleaved. That means it goes in one ear and out the other. Thus the "tutorial" system is extensive but is not actually suitable for true beginners. A better way to hook beginners would be to rapidly show them a quick-and-easy barely useful build without going into every detail of that build. Then get the player launched
date: guide them to another system/whatever and dock. Travelling to the other system should show some of the features/drawbacks of the build. Then enhance the craft. Launch. Script an easy Skirmish and guide them through it. Guide subsequent repairs. Return to dock. Buy replacements
hoursPlayed:
etc. That is a true tutorial -- what exists now is more akin to a one-time hovering tooltip.


The graphics look good and the complexity revealed thus far hints at greatness. Unfortunately the time and rote memorization it takes to get initially acquainted with this game keeps me from truly playing it. I've never truly gotten out of the hangar before I had to quit and at that point there is nothing exciting about the game that makes me want to return to it any time soon. Hence I can't recommend it."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAh, Kinetic Void. What can I say about this beauty? For starters, the ship building is easy to use an monumentally powerful. While I have encountered some games that give you about 20 pieces and 20 spots to put them, Kinetic Void's ship builder truly lets you build whatever you want. If you don't like using the node system to place pieces, there is a freehand mode that lets you put anything anywhere. There are tons of pieces and all are resizable. On the largest setting, the pieces are insanely massive, and the more creative will find many pieces to build full size replicas of some of sci-fi's most famous ships. But this game isn't just space ship builder simulator. It has an incredibly well made space exploration portion. The ships to show their size quite well, as maneuvering a giant capital ship take much longer than a small agile fighter. There are tons of weapons of different damages and types and there are also preset ships for new players to use. In conclusion, Kinetic Void is an absolute masterpiece and I cannot reccomend it more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Basically a 3rd person space flight simulator, but with some very interesting twists. Most notabely the ability to design your own space ship, designs which NPC's are known to use as well, to keep the playing field balanced.

Add to that relational status with numerous factions and reasonably large universe (can be set upon creating one) and you have yourself a great arena to test these designs in. Don't have an enemy? Create one by just randomly shooting ships that happen to pass by. You could always go mining or salvaging derelict craft for resources as well.

Great graphics and awesome soundtrack, easy to learn controls, but sometimes not so clear on what, though optional, you mission objectives are make this a nice addition to any collection.

There are some problems though, crashes, editor that has trouble doing certain things, but nothing really game breaking. And although I'm not much of a multiplayer gamer, I can see some real potential in that latest addition as well.

Bare in mind though that this is still an project in development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would recommend this game for most people, but not everyone. I have watched this game grow (and continue to do so) since July 2013 and am pleased by the progress that the developers have made so far, but there is still much work to be done in order to refine Kinetic Void. I would recommend this game to the following types of gamers:

-Gamers who enjoy being creative in taking parts and building something of their own, but poses the patience to have to tweak, rework, or even recreate what they make after major patches come out. This game is still early access so it is understandable that these things happen and the patches generally make things easier.

-People who enjoy a good RPG type simulation that takes place with ships, factions, and fleets, and can spend hours upon hours of trial and error to find out what works best in this game.

-People who have ever played Battlestar Galactica Online: the game has a similar feeling to it and I feel that people who enjoyed that MMO would feel right at home with Kinetic Void outside of the ship creation menu

-Peoplewho have played and enjoyed Kerbal Space Program: If you enjoyed the building mechanics in Kerbal, expect to enjoy Kinetic Void

-People with a lot of patience in general who can wait for something to blossom to its true potential.

I won’t lie, this game still has a lot of bugs (some are actually quite comical) but the Developers have done a good balance of both fixing these bugs as they come up and adding new content to the game, and I hope they continue to do so.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Worth getting just for the amazing ship yard system. It obviously isn't complete yet, and the lack of solid tutorials gives things a steeper than normal learning curve. But I have faith in this dev team to complete the task. They release updates frequently, and keep the community informed on their progress and plans.

Seriously though... If you enjoy heavy customization the ship yard and construction system alone makes this game worthwhile. I do find myself hoping that the devs create a few more options in certain categories, but the possibilities are already staggering with 5 part scales and massive assortment of pieces.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I only have a couple of hours on this game so far, and those hours were purely from me painstakingly putting together my space ship.

Having said that, I had an unbelievably good time doing so.  Even if the gameplay turns out to only be so-so, I'll still consider this money well spent.  The ship construction is incredibly good, both simple (though it takes some trial and error to figure out the eccentricities) and complex enough to satisfy... well... someone who has spent hours building a single ship.
Something else that blew me away is the soundtrack!  I was nervous when the first track ended (mere minutes into my shipbuilding exploration!) that it would just repeat.  Nope!  Although tracks did repeat over my multi-hour session, there were enough and I enjoyed every single one so much that I was entertained the entire time.

In sum, based on a couple of hours of gameplay; a fantastic ship builder and gorgeous soundtrack make me think this may join my list of all-time favorite games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DON'T  BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW!!!
Even than the core idea seems interesting, the game is in so early development phase that there is no fun of any kind.
The key feature of this game is the possibility of to design and to build your own customized ship from scratch.
Other key feature is the randomization of galaxies but, it seems you have nothing to do with planets, there is no interaction.
Engine is a hard CPU consuming and doesn't seem to be optimized.
Lot of hours flying in a void space, where nothing happens.
Lack of history board, or goals or missions.
No user's manual. No key bindings. Weak user interface.
Map does nothing for you. You never know where your ship is and, which is the distance to any potential target (except if they are in your range).
Making it short, this 'game' needs a HUGE effort before it can be called a game.

reviewText: This game ran out of money and development has ceased to exist.  The game never got out of Alpha.  Just know that if you buy this game, it has no story, no AI, and no support. The ship designer is actually quite deep and the graphics were not all that bad.  The studio that made the game just had a bad economic model.  Hire programmers to develop a game with revenue from steam and kickstarter.  When money ran out, the programmers ran out too.  The end.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Development stopped or stalled on this shell of a game. Looking back through change logs of this game since it's release, there seem to be no improvements in actual gameplay, which is to say, there isn't any gameplay. If you manage to launch your pre-fabbed ship into the 'void' without freezing your computer solid, you've experienced all this game has to offer. If the idea of shp building is what appeals to you, try Kerbal Space Program, or Space Engineers. Both early access Steam games with ship building AND gameplay.
I understand early releases are made for playtesting and refinement, but there is nothing to play or test here.

reviewText:

In substance I would give 7.0 over 10. In my opinion it is worth the price set.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With the knowledge that it is an early access game, I am going to hold my tongue, or fingers a little. While I love space sims especially with that sandbox aspect I have a few complaints.

I started a career mode game so I could try it out. I hadn't played the game in a few months and wanted to see what was new... Not much was for starters, but that is to be expected, a lot of Early Access games don't have a lot of updates (Except for something like Space Engineers ). I picked the random parts and started building my ship. After 1 and a half hours of fumbling around both because of player error, and because its a little weird... I press launch only to have to put in subsystems. (no I couldn't read the tutorial, the UI freaked out and overlapped the words) Once I figure (sortof) that out, I launch it... The game loads, and within 5 seconds.. not anymore or any less, I was destroyed... So I tried again... and again... Only to end with the same result. Then I go to the main menu, and decide to try and load a 65 part ship from my workshop... It loaded, and a warning popped up saying that I had to many parts and it might crash... 65 parts, and I hadn't even added the big shiny hanger doors and millions of hanger control modules I wanted to.. So I decided to launch it (and after some more subsystem fumbling) got it launched. I fought off the army outside, and then got up to my max speed of 57. In space. In a simulation game. Then I look at the directory, and find out if I press T and turn off a shield thing that stops me I will go faster... So a top speed of 83. Way to go for the USS Gweepo... A new speed Record. Then I point it towards the nearest planet hoping I will be able to use the new mining laser thing I put on to mine stuff off the planet. I watch as the numbers slowly decrease from 202.1 to 202 to 201.9 and so on. After seeing that I did the only sensible thing. Tried to warp towards the planet... Only to warp into it. Ten minutes later I spawn again and warp (correctly luckily) to the planet and try and land on it. Only to die again.

Overall, I think this game CAN have potential if the devs iron out the bugs that it has. They (he\she\it, I dunno) seem to be very interested in te steam community so I give them points just for that.. Also, collision, and speed especially when it says that if you press the T" key it activates Newtonian flight
date: should mean I have a fixed acceleration
recommended: up to an infinite speed. Not just a faster speed. Big ships need a boost

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even for an early access game Kinetic Void offers solid game play with consitant updates by the developers. I've spent most of the time just building different ships in the game. The amount of detail allowed in customizing the ship can be staggering. You place hull parts and engines, fill those with subsystems that affect the ship in different ways.

Currently you can take it out and fly around, shoot other ships or mine. There are also factions in game that you can do missions for that are generated for you as you are out in space. Newtonian physics as an option adds a great layer to the flight. Nothing better than strafing around at high speeds while in a dog fight. At this stage I can whole heartedly recommend this purchase, especially with devs that respond to the community.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kinetic Void is a game that allows you to build your own spacecraft from scratch. Very few games do that and less run this smooth. I use a some-what slow and old computer, but KV still runs. With the help of the steam workshop and community, you can upload your ships and load someone else's. You can also make several ships in one world and each world is randomly generated. I've played my fair share of EVE: Online and the knowledge of ships has only improved by playing this game. I look forward to tech trees and other advancements in the campaign.

reviewText:
This is the only game I have ever played that has a warp drive of sorts (except star trek online). You can build your own ships from scratch, and make truly any design you desire. NPCs will also have these ships available, meaning you can give them ships that equal your own in terms of power (so the game changes as you become more inventive). It is tricky to manage the subsystems along with the space of the ship, but once you know what you're doing everything should be fine

The worst thing about this game would have to be...the repetitiveness of placing weapons. You have to select your turret each time, and place it so it looks right. The mirroring isn't as finely tuned as the mirroring in Kerbal Space Program. Additionally, once the turret is down you must go into the weapons subsystem and select what each individual turret should be equiped with. Making large ships with lots of subsystems can get tedious and/or confusing, especially if you want everything to look even (which I do).

A good point, the galactic relations allow you to make enemies and allies, which can be fun. Trading is something that I haven't yet figured out, which leads me to believe that it's poorly explained, however overall this is a fun game if you want to build your own ships and fight others in space.

The main thing that would make this game a massive improvement would be multiplayer, better controls, better graphics, simpler mechanics to build ships, and getting rid of a few mission scripts that don't work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, this review covers the game in its current state (D14.2)
When I first started up the game all I got was audio na dno visuals...
After looking through forums I found this was common for Macs and has been happening for quite a while...
A major bug that should have been fixed ages ago. (the bug can be fixed by going into the display.cfg folder and changing the resolution to your monitor's native resolution and turning off AA)
When I first started to design my ship I noticed the graphics could be improved a bit...
But overall I enjoyed the ship creation part of the game!
After you leave the hanger and launch into space,  the game is rather borring...
A lot more could be added (I guess of course I haven't played this part of the game too much)

Overall the game sounds fun and is a great idea, but it has a lot to be added and I personally would wait until a later date to buy this game.

reviewText: I would definitely recommend Kinetic Void, however with a warning. The game as it is, is a lot of fun in my opinion. The ship building aspect is very entertaining and allows players to create whatever sort of ship they please, from small one-man fighters to giant hulking cruisers. Once out in space the game can get a little empty. There are missions to do which give you an immediate objective or you can go out and sort of do your own thing. There is mining for resources and diplomacy which allows you to go into a hostile system and hunt enemy ships for bounties. It can get a little old though. In my opinion, more diverse missions should be added as well as an option to select mission based on what kind of playstyle you have (maybe a mission interface at space stations?). This would allow players who want to play as a pirate to do raid missions, miners to do resource gathering, etc... I also think smaller stations should be implemented that do not have shipyards, but rather some sort of other funtions (ie. Smugglers' dens, military instalations, trade centers, etc?).  One more thing I would hope to see is more interaction with friendly faction ships, because as of now, friendlies just sort of drift around space and don't do much. I'd like to see something like, escort missions for friendly factions, or the possibility of hiring wingmen to fly around with you and assist in combat.\n\nI think the game is deifitely on the right track, it IS a fun game as is but it still needs some work, I hope a DEV gets the chance to read this review and think about the suggestions I've made. I think implementing  some of them would make the game feel fuller once the fun of ship building wears out or you've run out of ship ideas.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, here's how it works.

You don't play the game for the gameplay, the plot, the great dialogue, or the well designed missions, quite simply because none of those things exist.

You set the game to creative mode, and design a ship. Undock, and immediately start testing the weapons.

Then you design another ship. This one takes almost an hour. Undock, test the weapons, eventually you die.

You design yet another ship, six hours it takes, it looks badass. Save, undock, and you crash the game because, who knew, a 10:1 scale death star made of thousands of object will still crash your game.

But you don't care, because the game's more about designing ships, the weapons, etc, and testing them than it is about gameplay...

For now.
voteText: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kinetic Void is a very Early Alpha game. A few annoying bugs and glitches which hopefully get fixed sooner rather than later. The ship building is amazing. despite the bug and glitches. It is fantastic. Easily the best part of the game with me. Space flight is not too bad. I think as and when future updates come out then it will improve. Right now you just fly around shooting stuff, mining asteroids, selling the ores and building bigger better ships. Would like to see the planned economy come out. That should improve the gameplay a lot, Would also like to see the ability to start a factions, take space stations, mining stations, claim systems, Have NPC ships fly around the galaxy mining, and defending territory.

Performance of the game is very good. On High end hardware the game runs over 110 FPS on maxmimum settings.  Graphics are very good in most places. In some places like the engine trails, they are pretty poor, at least to myself.

Should you buy this game? In my opinion yes. While right now there are bugs and glitches, which is to be expected in an early alpha game, The future looks bright, with the developers looking well into the future with possible multiplayer and DLC content.

reviewText:
I don't have a whole lot of time put in this game but I can say that the game is worth the money.

<<WILL UPDATE AS GAME PROGRESSES!!>>

Pros:
--Customization: Create and command ships of your very making or download one of the many on the workshop and cause havoc. Also if you manipulate the game files you can have your created ships be specific to factions.
--Open Ended: Do what you want, when you want. No forced actions.
--Beautiful environment.
--Balanced Ships (Can't create an ultimate fighter with world destroying guns)
--ACTIVE DEV TEAM! these guys are great and are always making updates to the game. They will listen to the community.

Cons:
--Should've stayed in early access a little longer still a few bugs here and there, but then again what new release game nowadays doesn't?
--Kinda empty: for a sci-fi space sim it seems kinda empty.
--No tutorial.

In all the game has potential to be the best space sim out there but yes it still has some stuff needed.

reviewText: The reports here are crazy. It seemed to me that the community got spoiled from DEV interaction that they expected the world. I haven't played this since it's pre beta phase but what i noticed is this. Not only can you make just about any ship you can imagine but any ship you make will be ingame flown by npc's. So what i did is subscribed to about 300+ player made ships and guess what... some how they are floating around in the game world. You can decide how large/ how many star systems/ factions are in your game at the start, as well as do missions for them. but this seems like if your dream is to not be limited by developer made ships you can fight any number of different space battles.\n\nI just wish they added the ability to buy/sell full ships in the store. That way someone who was playing the regular mode without infinite money and parts could save up enough to buy one of the ships on the steam work shop or even a generic basic ship without having to make every detail. That could make the economy more interesting as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not entirely a waste of money.





Pros:
~ More intricate ship building: Less blocky designs, more artistic designs seem to be possible with this game.
~ More customization
~ Factions present, hostile and non-hostile.
~ Pretty good graphics, and runs very well. (Have not tested FPS with large ship builds yet, will do later.)
~ Vast space system.

Cons:
~ Guide and tutorial needs work. Bigger font size. Different color than the rest of the screen, make it big and bold etc, otherwise players are going to ignore it at first (like I did) and then kick themselves later for ignoring it. It took me 10 minutes to locate the information needed to simply apply Subsystems. If it takes that long for an average player to deduce that, interest will wane quickly.



Y'know, honestly... I was going to write a negative review...but while writing this piece I've had a chance to reflect upon the game itself.

Right now it IS indeed worth the price. $20.00 USD for a Beta isn't too bad at all, especially given the wealth of content in game, not to mention the very awesome ship builder thing (once you get the hang of it).

For anyone thinking of buying this game.... be warned its not your garden variety Minecraft-esque Ship Building game. It takes some thought and a bit of patience to learn how to build a ship, how to make it fly etc etc. Its not easy, but it is rewarding once you've mastered how the game works.


Right now I'd give the game a 6/10. Its above average, but I'd like to come back and review it when its out of Early-Access / Beta etc.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game shows great potential, who knows, it could become something great, the building mechanics are brilliant and the detail is real nice.
but the D12 update made me lose some faith in this game, they completely messed it up, infact i will go to say they F@$!ed it up, hard, i have never seen such a mess up, the building menu is almost imposible to navigate, one bad move and you have to restart your entire ship, bug bugs and oh look, more BUGS, and heven forbid, i do not want to see anything passed the building menu. but not the entire update is a mess up, they now have paint styles and even if the menu for ship building is so far gone and messed up, it has this professional look to it and just screams Si:Fi, and the creativity is real good, i can spend hours on it and the part where you finaly fly your ship out of dock and test it, makes you feel like a boss, cause normal, if you are on creative, it owns (a good suggestion when its your first time, play on creative) and having hardpoints that are animmated, and watching them activate, makes me want to just imagin one day having multiplayer and jumping and and being the capital ship of a huge fleet in the middle of a war.
even IF they messed up D12 and i losed some faith in this game, it could most likely recover, i just hope they recover before people lose hope for this game entirely,
this game is great and i am willing to forgive the game and the devs for the D12 update, (only if they dont mess D13 up like they did with D12) but for a suggestion, wait a little while, or get this when its on sale, dont get it at full price right now, cause this game is sitting on the edge of a deep hole, and if the devs dont get it together and work on the menu, then this game could lose its fans, but
anyway i give the game, 6.48/10 steam stamps (thats my rating system: steam stamps)

Edit:
Now, i would like to say, that, dear Devs, you made D13 one of the best updates.
Building Is WAY more responsive plus, with all the new tools that i just found, they allow you to do New things, like the one tool (i forgot its name) allows the player to move one part into another, Allowing for some rather good Ships, myself included. so, i have gained all my hope back thanks to the devs fixing the things that where wrong in D12, and overhauling the entire game with D13, so, if you are reading this, and you have not bought the game, then i would call you crazy to click off the page and not buy it, but before you do buy it (unless you want to show your support) wait till muiltplayer come out.
i re-rate this game 8.8/10 steam stamps (like i said before, i rating system)
(additional: if you want me to rate a game, PM me)


Edit #2 (Final)
This game has gone to a whole new level of epic with D14.2 just because of the fact that now i can basicly hover right over a planet, go as about 30 meters from the ground without being blowen up, but there are somethings that could be impermented to make this game better, first off, landing gears, to land on a planet, second, just maybe, add someway of exploring a planet, with a vehicle or running around on the planets. there are alot of things that could be added, but those twos where the first things that came to mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Delivers on all the very worst tedium of a 4X game with almost none of the freedom or wonder.  The generated universes are very featureless and bland.  The combat is a snorefest.  A sad skeleton of a game built backwards from the ceiling down.  There's a neat ship creation system but with nothing compelling for you to do with the ships you create, it's utterly pointless.

The only entertainment I can find anyone having with the game thus far is creating ships with the generator and then posting them on the workshop.  Consider the game LEGO with spaceship parts, then.

I'm sure this review will get thumbs-downed like nuts from a bunch of apologists who would recommend the game to you on the basis of what it could be and not what it actually is.  Anyone who would recommend this game to their friends based on its current state is a poor friend to have.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really don't understand the design of this game. I liked the concept of it enough to buy it (obviously) but when I gave it a try found that it lacked well, a lot. Its not just the fact that this game is in alpha, its that it has an amazingly bad interface and control scheme, bad graphics and sound, and sub-zero immersion factor. Its like this is a ship building tool with a few minor non-ship building features. The ships look and fly like toys. There is no sense of flying a technical marvel of space travel, it just feels like you are taking your cardboard box out for a spin in the driveway. Let me put it this way, if Steam let me try this before buying, I would not have purchased it. My advise to the devs, play a few space games like Freespace, or EVE Online or Privateer or Indepence War or something then take a long hard look at Kinetic Void and make some much needed changes. Frankly I am shocked that anyone can even play this game is its current form. Kudos to you who find something of value in this game but it makes me wonder if any of you have played other space games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hi, I thought this game looked cool so I bought it. The initial part, the ship builder, was amazingly designed, only a tad confusing. After I created the ship, however, it spawned me in a galaxy. The flight controls were very confusing, and it would be nice to have a shipbuilding and flight tutorial added somewhere within the game to be easily accessed. Anyway, I pressed a wrong button and my ship exploded. Every time after that, my ship exploded. I have talked to the developer, Kaypix, and he says that all you have to do is create a new galaxy. Please don't get frustrated like I did. If you don't know what to do, Google will be your best friend, as well as amazing developers like Kaypix. I had a negative review, but I have changed my opinion. Buy this advanced game, but be sure you know exactly what you want when you get it, as the controls are confusing. Thanks again for your time.

-MCMayhem

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have very much enjoyed my experience in Kinetic Void thus far.  Currently, it reminds me of much of Digital Anvil/Microsoft Studio's Freelancer - a game I VERY much enjoyed for providing a rich, detailed universe.  Freelancer also had a wide range of systems and paths that a player could take, and allowed for customizable ships.

Kinetic Void ups the ship design aspect allowing for a completely customizable ship.  Runner, gunner, fighter, freighter...  armed to the teeth or built for speed - or ANYTHING in between.  Build a galaxy to play in.

There's a lot to see and do within the game, and I think having access to the design creativity of the Steam-going public as well as a talented design team will provide an excellent experience.

reviewText: I cannot recommend this game. They broke it. It used to be great - a sandbox experience where you could create any ship you wished, drag the file around in the directories, set up custom factions, create an entire universe with it's own factions, each with it's own style of ship (designed by you) and it's own alleigances / hostilities. Yeah. Not anymore. Now it's a dull, repetative, REALLY slow space game where by you need to mine ore, salvage ships and trade in a dull flying sim to make credits and upgrade your ship. Creating custom faction folders just causes a game crash now. The ship builder has a bunch of dumb restrictions that seriously limits the game's potential. Save your money. Man I wish I could go back to an older version.

reviewText:
This game is under developed, flawed, and broken. Frankly, it's gone from bad to worse through it's development. They throw out working systems in favor of new ones that introduce bugs that years later still arnt fixed, the UI makes no sense, the most interesting aspect, building is now horribly flawed and broken with menues that dont work properly, controls that dont always work or do what you tell them. Once you get out of the hangar and into the game, it dumps you into a universe that has no direction, with obscure and unintuitive controls.

I would give this game a solid 3/10 for being a neat concept, but being executed horribly. Maybe another +1 for the decent soundtrack which is rather nice, but that's about all they did well.

Going on their forums is little help too. The community is full of immaturity since any problem you bring up with is met with L2P noob" and other snide comments when you bring up questions like "Why did symetry stop working" or "What is that horrible constant scratching noise that wont go away?"

There are far better sandbox space games out there
date: dont waste your time or money."

reviewText:
This game is rather paltry on content at the moment, but has great potential. The devs are very friendly and are hard at work on it, though there are times when a month can pass by without any updates.
It is hard to get into, but just cruising around your galaxy with a ship you made is quite fun.
I'd give it a 7/10, wait and see.

If you are on the fence about getting it, just wait and see if becomes more than what it currently is. It is not bad, just very 'skeletal'.

EDIT: I realized the devs have not updated this game since January 2015, and even those were just small hotfixes. This game seems to be dead now, its developers abandoned it. Move along and find a different game.

reviewText: I bought this game when it launched. It has not improved since it was launched on Early Access, if anything the updates made the 'game' worse. What's now worse is that the game is abandonware and hasn't been updated once in fourteen months. The game is riddled with bugs and glitches. The only redeeming quality is the music, which was outsourced to Artem (I believe) and can be Googled without buying this trash. AVOID. Wish I could get my money back. Too many developers these days take your money promising the world, then after months of excuses, run off with your money. Steam won't refund anything past 14 days so you're screwed really. Out of a good number of EA titles I've bought, only one (Project Zomboid) has been a success and hasn't robbed me.

(Original positive review) Great. Steam Workshop already, and a developer who joins in with the community. This game is going to be superb.
They are concentrating on all the right things first. Procedurally generated universes which you can save and come back to, user made ships, plenty of videos and tutorials to get you started. If they are not careful they'll give Early-Access a good name ;)

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY!

Game has not been updated since January of LAST YEAR, that is as of this review, 1 year and 3 months ago.

Last developer interaction with the community was a request for a programmer LAST AUGUST. Well apparently he ran out of money and won't man up and clearly state  on the store page that development on the game has stopped and it is now an AS-IS product.

The game had premise, it is enoyable for what little it offers, but I can not in good conscience recommend this current indie mentality of not taking responsibility for keeping your PAYING customers informed when the game fails and you have to abandon it.  Games fail all the time, you run our of money, I get that, but be a fricking man and OWN UP TO IT.
